titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the James A. Kelly papers 1977.342
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Matthew Gorham
titlestmt.sponsor: This collection was processed and described as part of the project, "Uncovering the Secrets of Brooklyn's 19th Century Past: Creation to Consolidation," funded by the Council on Library and Information Resources, with additional support from The Gladys Krieble Delmas Foundation.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2011-11-11T14:02-0500

change.item: Additional content contributed by Nicholas Pavlik,

bioghist.head: Biographical note
bioghist.p: James A. Kelly was born in Ireland. He served as Deputy County Clerk for Brooklyn form 1926 to 1964, and was the Borough of Brooklyn Historian from 1944 to 1971.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The James A. Kelly papers span the period 1916 to 1965 and measure 0.1 linear feet. Included in the papers are correspondence; photostats of songs written by James A. Kelly; news clippings dated 1949 to 1966; biographical and genealogical notes; materials from the Long Island Historical Society testimonial dinner; memorabilia of the 100th anniversary of Prospect Park; and a collection of notes, correspondence and documents regarding Jennie Jerome, the mother of Winston Churchill. Also included are photographs of various subjects, including a function held in honor of Kelly, Kelly's appointment as historian of the borough of Brooklyn, the unveiling of a plaque in honor of Jennie Jerome, and other events commemorating Brooklyn history.

processinfo.head: Processing Information note
processinfo.p: Minimally processed to the collection level.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item, date (if known); James A. Kelly papers, 1977.342, Box and Folder number; Brooklyn Historical Society.
